questions.question: Which King of France, crowned in 987, is considered the founder of the Capetian dynasty?
questions.note: By ascending the throne in 987, Hugh Capet inaugurated a new line of monarchs that would rule France for more than eight centuries.

questions.question: Which King of France, nicknamed the “Sun King,” reigned from 1643 to 1715?
questions.note: Louis XIV centralized power, built Versailles, and supported the arts, ensuring France’s cultural influence across Europe.

questions.question: Which King of France, known for signing the Edict of Nantes in 1598, brought an end to the French Wars of Religion?
questions.note: Henry IV granted Protestants a measure of tolerance, easing internal religious tensions.

questions.question: Which medieval king, canonized in 1297, is often seen as the embodiment of the ideal Christian king?
questions.note: Louis IX led crusades, reformed the justice system, and built religious monuments, symbolizing a pious and just monarch.

questions.question: Which King of France was executed in 1793, marking the end of absolute monarchy?
questions.note: Overthrown by the Revolution, Louis XVI symbolizes the fall of the Ancien Régime and the start of a new political era.

questions.question: Which king restored the monarchy after Napoleon’s fall, with a constitutional charter that limited his powers?
questions.note: Louis XVIII tried to reconcile the revolutionary legacy with monarchical tradition, ushering in the Bourbon Restoration.

questions.question: Which king built the Sainte-Chapelle in Paris in the 13th century to house the relics of the Passion?
questions.note: The Sainte-Chapelle reflects the prestige of the Capetian kingdom and the king’s devotion.

questions.question: Which king, supported by Joan of Arc, managed to restore royal authority during the Hundred Years’ War?
questions.note: Charles VII reconquered territory from the English, consolidating royal power and ending a long period of turmoil.

questions.question: Which young king, son of Henry II and Catherine de’ Medici, died at age 16, leaving an unstable kingdom?
questions.note: The premature death of Francis II (1559–1560) left France in the grip of the Wars of Religion.

questions.question: Which king, who succeeded Louis XIV, failed to reform finances and administration in depth before the Revolution?
questions.note: Despite a long reign, Louis XV could not resolve chronic financial problems, unintentionally paving the way for the monarchy’s collapse.

questions.question: Which hero, a former convict, embodies redemption and kindness in Victor Hugo’s 'Les Misérables'?
questions.note: Jean Valjean, once sentenced for stealing bread, symbolizes moral transformation and compassion in 19th-century society.

questions.question: Which young Gascon hero from Alexandre Dumas pursues glory and honor alongside Athos, Porthos, and Aramis?
questions.note: In 'The Three Musketeers' (1844), d’Artagnan embodies boldness, courage, and honor, hallmarks of the swashbuckling hero.

questions.question: Which character, famous for his nose and wit, is the hero of Edmond Rostand’s play 'Cyrano de Bergerac' (1897)?
questions.note: Cyrano, a poet and swordsman, is a romantic hero ready to sacrifice, valuing honor and beautiful words over fulfilling his love.

questions.question: Which hero created by Voltaire travels the world hoping to learn whether we live in 'the best of all possible worlds'?
questions.note: 'Candide' (1759) is a philosophical tale criticizing blind optimism; Candide embodies innocence confronted with the harshness of reality.

questions.question: In Alexandre Dumas’ 'The Count of Monte Cristo', which hero, unjustly imprisoned, orchestrates a meticulous revenge against his enemies?
questions.note: Edmond Dantès symbolizes resilience and the thirst for justice in an epic that questions morality, guilt, and forgiveness.

questions.question: Which character from Stendhal, torn between social ambition and romantic passion, is a complex hero in 'The Red and the Black'?
questions.note: Julien Sorel reflects the tension between personal ambition and the moral and social constraints of the Bourbon Restoration.

questions.question: Which humanist giant, hero of François Rabelais’ stories, represents an ideal of knowledge, freedom, and hearty appetite?
questions.note: In 'Gargantua' and 'Pantagruel' (16th century), Rabelais offers a giant hero celebrating learning, feasting, and criticism of dogma.

questions.question: Which hero, deformed yet deeply moving, the bell-ringer of Notre-Dame de Paris, represents a tragic and solitary ideal?
questions.note: Quasimodo, in Victor Hugo’s novel (1831), is a deformed anti-hero who embodies sensitivity hidden beneath a monstrous appearance.

questions.question: Which little hero, created by Antoine de Saint-Exupéry, travels from planet to planet to understand human nature and friendship?
questions.note: The Little Prince (1943) is a symbolic hero and spokesperson for a universal philosophy about love, childhood, and responsibility.

questions.question: In medieval French literature, which Round Table knight celebrated by Chrétien de Troyes embodies the chivalric ideal?
questions.note: Lancelot, a courtly and valiant hero, symbolizes impossible love, loyalty, and the quest for spiritual perfection in the Matter of Britain.

questions.question: Which French basketball player, a four-time NBA champion with the San Antonio Spurs, was named Finals MVP in 2007?
questions.note: Tony Parker (born 1982) made history for French and international basketball by becoming the first French player named NBA Finals MVP.

questions.question: Which French swimmer won the 400m freestyle at the Athens Olympics in 2004?
questions.note: Laure Manaudou was the first French female swimmer to win an Olympic title, opening a new era for French swimming.

questions.question: Which French biathlete, a five-time Olympic champion, is one of the greatest champions in the sport’s history?
questions.note: Martin Fourcade dominated world biathlon for nearly a decade, winning the overall World Cup (Crystal Globe) 13 times.

questions.question: Which French tennis player, winner of Roland-Garros in 1983, is the last Frenchman to win the men’s singles title there?
questions.note: Yannick Noah remains the last Frenchman to lift the Coupe des Mousquetaires, defeating Mats Wilander in the final.

questions.question: Which French pole vaulter broke the indoor world record with a 6.16m jump in 2014?
questions.note: By clearing 6.16m in Donetsk, Renaud Lavillenie broke the legendary record held for more than 20 years by Sergey Bubka.

questions.question: Which French judoka, a ten-time world champion, is considered one of the greatest judokas of all time?
questions.note: Teddy Riner has amassed world and Olympic medals, becoming one of the greatest legends in international judo.

questions.question: Which French driver, a nine-time WRC Rally World Champion, holds an unmatched record in motorsport history?
questions.note: Sébastien Loeb and his co-driver Daniel Elena dominated the discipline, winning nine consecutive titles from 2004 to 2012.

questions.question: Which rugby player, named World Player of the Year in 2021, is a key figure in the resurgence of the French national team?
questions.note: Nicknamed “le minot” early in his career at Castres, Antoine Dupont became a leader for both France and Toulouse.

questions.question: Which French cyclist, nicknamed “The Badger,” won the Tour de France five times between 1978 and 1985?
questions.note: Bernard Hinault is among the rare riders to have won all three Grand Tours (France, Italy, Spain), leaving a major mark on French cycling history.

questions.question: Which French handball player, a three-time Olympic champion (2008, 2012, 2020) and four-time world champion, is often considered one of the best players in history?
questions.note: Nikola Karabatic was a key figure of “Les Experts” (the nickname of the French national handball team) during their many successes.

questions.question: Which Frankish king, crowned Emperor of the West in Rome in the year 800, consolidated a vast empire covering much of Europe?
questions.note: Charlemagne (768–814) unified an immense territory and revived the arts, education, and culture in what would be called the Carolingian Renaissance.

questions.question: Which treaty in 843 divided the Carolingian Empire among Charlemagne’s grandsons and laid the groundwork for future European nations?
questions.note: Signed between Lothair, Louis the German, and Charles the Bald, this treaty marked the start of the fragmentation of the Carolingian Empire.

questions.question: Which Capetian king, nicknamed the “Iron King,” waged a fierce struggle against the Knights Templar and forced the papacy to settle in Avignon?
questions.note: Philip IV the Fair (1285–1314) dismantled the Order of the Temple and secured the papacy’s move to Avignon, triggering the Avignon Papacy (1309–1377).

questions.question: Which medieval king, crowned in 1226, is famous for his piety, judicial reforms, and the construction of the Sainte-Chapelle?
questions.note: Saint Louis was canonized in 1297. He also led two crusades (1248 and 1270) and embodied the image of the ideal Christian king.

questions.question: Which battle in 1415 was a heavy defeat for French chivalry during the Hundred Years’ War?
questions.note: The Battle of Agincourt (25 October 1415) was one of France’s greatest military disasters, opening the way for English advances.

questions.question: Which French national heroine, born in Domrémy around 1412, led the French army to lift the siege of Orléans and enabled Charles VII’s coronation in Reims?
questions.note: Nicknamed “the Maid,” Joan of Arc was burned at the stake in 1431, but her military and symbolic role helped shape the end of the Hundred Years’ War.

questions.question: Which dynasty, founded by Hugh Capet in 987, ruled France until 1328?
questions.note: The Capetian dynasty continued through its cadet branches (Valois, Bourbons), forming the longest royal lineage in French history.

questions.question: Which great duchess, ruler of an immense province, married Louis VII of France and then Henry II Plantagenet of England, playing a central role in Franco-English conflicts?
questions.note: Her marriage to Henry II, King of England, transferred Aquitaine to the English crown, intensifying tensions that would lead to the Hundred Years’ War.

questions.question: Which Duke of Burgundy, nicknamed “the Bold,” strengthened his duchy’s autonomy during the Hundred Years’ War and was a major player in French politics?
questions.note: Son of King John II of France, Philip the Bold (1363–1404) was the first great Valois Duke of Burgundy, building a power that rivaled the French crown.

questions.question: Which French knight, a leading commander of the First Crusade, became Advocate of the Holy Sepulchre after the capture of Jerusalem in 1099?
questions.note: Godfrey of Bouillon (c. 1060–1100) refused to be crowned King of Jerusalem, preferring the title of Advocate (protector) of the Holy Sepulchre.

questions.question: Which French chemist, author of the 1789 'Elementary Treatise of Chemistry', is considered the “father of modern chemistry”?
questions.note: Antoine Lavoisier (1743–1794) identified and named oxygen, helped found modern chemistry, and introduced the idea of conservation of mass.

questions.question: Which French physicist discovered the natural radioactivity of uranium in 1896, paving the way for Pierre and Marie Curie’s work?
questions.note: Henri Becquerel (1852–1908) received the Nobel Prize in Physics (1903) with Pierre and Marie Curie for discoveries on radioactivity.

questions.question: Which French mathematician and physicist gave his name to the SI unit of electric current?
questions.note: André-Marie Ampère (1775–1836) was a founder of electromagnetism. The ampere (A) is the unit of electric current.

questions.question: Which scientist, a two-time Nobel laureate (Physics and Chemistry), worked on radioactivity and discovered polonium and radium?
questions.note: Marie Curie (1867–1934) was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize and the only person to win two in two different scientific fields.

questions.question: Which French mathematician and physicist, author of the 'Analytical Theory of Heat' (1822), also gave his name to a famous transform in mathematics?
questions.note: Fourier series and the Fourier transform are fundamental tools in applied mathematics and physics.

questions.question: Which French naturalist proposed the inheritance of acquired characteristics and offered one of the first evolutionary frameworks for species?
questions.note: Well before Darwin, Lamarck (1744–1829) proposed a theory of species transformation, though his ideas differ from modern evolutionary theory.

questions.question: Which French astronomer and mathematician proposed the nebular hypothesis to explain the formation of the Solar System?
questions.note: In 'Exposition of the System of the World' (1796), Laplace imagined the Sun and planets forming from a primordial nebula.

questions.question: Which French naturalist, known as the Comte de Buffon, wrote the monumental 'Natural History' in the 18th century?
questions.note: Buffon (1707–1788) helped lay the foundations of modern natural history, describing many animal and plant species in detail.

questions.question: Which French engineer and oceanographer, co-inventor of the aqua-lung in 1943 with Émile Gagnan, greatly advanced knowledge of the oceans?
questions.note: Commander Cousteau (1910–1997) popularized underwater exploration through films and founded the Cousteau Society.

questions.question: Which French mathematician and philosopher, author of 'Discourse on the Method', also made major contributions to analytic geometry?
questions.note: Descartes (1596–1650) pioneered analytic geometry, and his famous 'cogito ergo sum' stands at the foundation of modern philosophy.
